climbs.name: Thermal Mass
climbs.fa: Jay Foley, Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharp

content.description: This is probably the line to do at Solar Asylum.  Stem up the open book, I'd put it in the hard 11 range off the ground.  (May want to stick-clip 1st bolt, or avoid the start entirely by climbing easy ledges to the right.).  Pull through a series of pumpy roofs (very cool!) and step left on the ledge at 60'.  A bolted boulder problem and mantle gains a pedestal.  Jump (or reach) for the next ledge and go to the top.
content.location: Center of the alcove, starts in a slick open book.

climbs.name: Sunshine
climbs.fa: Jay Foley, Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharp

content.description: A great climb at Solar Asylum.  Boulder up just left of the arete to start.  The bolted lines split at the 2nd bolt- stay right to stay on Sunshine.  Pull through juggy blocky roofs to a large ledge.  Lieback up the headwall crack in the white wall, rock over left, and make cruxy pumpy face moves to a wonderful hold.  Face climb past another bolt to the chains.
content.location: Sunshine starts at the left side of the alcove, just left of an arete.

climbs.name: Sun Salute
climbs.fa: Jay Foley, Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharp

content.description:
Sun Salute has a great steep juggy first half, a more vertical crack/face climbing finish.  This climb shares a lot of climbing, including the start and finish, with the easier sections of "Solar Gain" (5.12c). 

  Start at the right side of the alcove.  Climb up and pull through numerous blocky roofs on great holds; you don't normally don't get to climb roofs this steep for the 5.11- grade!  So good! After the steeps, don't continue up the slick bolted arete: this is "Solar Gain" 5.12c.  Instead, step left to a finger crack and climb up that.  At the top of the finger crack, move out right, and climb a finger crack through the final headwall.
content.location: This climb starts at the right side of the white alcove.

climbs.name: Squatter's Rights
climbs.fa: Jay Foley w Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharpe

content.description: Leftmost bolt line that goes to the left headwall crack.  With the bolts, its now fully indepedent of the 2 climbs to its right.  Some cool face climbing and hand cracks lead to trickier sections at the 3rd tier and the headwall crack.
content.location: Begins left of a very small pine tree, and stays well left of the pine tree at 30'.

content.description: A bouldery start leads to easier climbing above then climb through steep jugs to a nasty ledge and gain the crack above.Then step left to the bullet headwall roof and bouldery crux above. It is also  possible to stay in the upper crack and trad climb to the Solar Gain anchors 5.10.
content.location: Bolt line up smooth face five feet right of Sunshine

climbs.name: Right Again
climbs.fa: Jay Foley w Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharpe

content.description: Rightmost line to the headwall.  With the bolts, it's fully independent from the climbs to its left.  I don't remember much on this one.  It had a face climbing start and passed a couple of rubbly ledges, with the best climbing being on the headwall.
content.location: Bolted line that is to the right of the pine tree at 30' up.

climbs.name: Onsight Rights
climbs.fa: Jay Foley w Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharpe

content.description: Middle bolt line to the headwall.  Starts just right of the tiny pine tree with a tricky start off the ground, followed by some easier rambling between ledges.  The central headwall crack is the crux, with some pretty sweet liebacking.
content.location: Starts just right of the tiny pine tree, passes the pine tree at 30' up to its left.

content.description: A nice long move off pockets at the second bolt leads to a roof with a crux crimp high above the lip, pull this to gain easier ground then rest up for the tricky crux headwall at the top.
content.location: The first route you come to and the farthest left on the crag.

content.description: Mostly 5.9 climbing with a technical crux near the top.Start just right of the steep roofs and follow low angle fractured and pocketed rock past two bolts for about sixty feet.Then step right and gain a smooth corner with a fixed pin. This route was originally led without bolts but the two bolts have now been added to the start. Still a trad route and well worth the effort.
content.location: This is the first route to the right of the steep bolted routes, about ten feet right of Solar Gain.   Originally described in Taos Rock: climbingschoolusa.com/taosr…

climbs.name: Creek Feet
climbs.fa: Jay Foley w Joel Tinl, Sam Lambie, Dave Sharpe

content.description: Overhanging gold camalot crack through 2 roofs!! Yes you need more of this in your life!Non-descript climbing leads to a bolt and the 2nd ledge below the roof crack.  The first roof diagonals leftward and you lose the feet.  The second roof is a 1-2' step in which the crack switches corners from left facing to right facing.  Above this, step right and finish up a fingers dihedral to the anchor.
content.protection: Standard rack with extras in the hand sizes. 2-bolt anchor
content.location: To the right of the bolted climbs leading to the headwall cracks, look for the sweet handcracks through the overhanging roofs.

content.description: Winter Climbing outdoors in Taos! A veritable sun-trap, the One hundred foot tall Solar Asylum remains in the shade until late morning (good for summer) and then the sun bakes the wall in the afternoon and evening. It is climbable on all but the coldest days of winter as well as nice and  cool on summer mornings before noon. There are a dozen routes (sport, mixed, and trad) with overhanging, featured, blocky lower thirds and upper head walls with technical, clean face and crack climbing. Top ropes can be set from above on some routes. See Taos Rock from Sharpend press orclimbtaos.com for more route info.
